fig.title: The multiple features of the Plasmodium berghei liver stage tubovesicular network (LS‐TVN).
fig.label: Figure 1
fig.sd-panel: A) Live confocal imaging of liver stage P. berghei expressing UIS4‐mCherry and cytoplasmic GFP reveals different morphologies of the LS‐TVN: elongated membrane clusters (left), vesicles in the host cell cytoplasm (center), and a thin tubule protruding from the PVM (right). Live imaging was performed 20 h after infection of hepatoma cells. Features are marked with white arrowheads.

B) The UIS4‐ and IBIS1‐positive tubules rapidly extend from and retract to the PVM. Confocal time‐lapse imaging of a UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing parasite at 22 h (top) and an IBIS1‐mCherry‐expressing parasite at 26 h (bottom) after infection of hepatoma cells. Tubules are indicated with a yellow arrow, and the time is shown in minutes and seconds.

C) Imaging of IBIS1‐mCherry‐expressing P. berghei reveals similar features of the LS‐TVN, i.e. elongated membrane cluster (left), vesicles in the host cell cytoplasm (center), and a membrane tubule (right). Infected cells were fixed 26 h post‐infection and imaged by epifluorescence microscopy. Features are indicated with a yellow arrowhead. Scale bars, 10 µm.

D) Quantification of the distinct UIS4‐ and IBIS1‐positive membranous structures in fixed infected hepatoma cells at three different time points: 6 h after infection (the period of sporozoite transformation into exo‐erythrocytic forms), 24 h after infection (onset of parasite replication and growth), and 48 h after infection (mature liver stages). Values are shown as mean (± SD) from three separate wells (n = 100 per well) of one experiment and are representative of two experimental repetitions.

fig.title: The morphology of the UIS4-positive LS‐TVN.
fig.label: Figure 2

sd-panel.p: Hepatoma cells infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA parasites were fixed and stained with anti-UIS4 and anti-HSP70 A) Some UIS4‐positive vesicles are tethered to the PVM as 'beads‐ona‐string'. Infected cell fixed 24 h post‐infection.

fig.sd-panel: B) The UIS4‐mCherry features we detect in live imaging of UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing P. berghei, i.e. elongated membrane clusters (left), vesicles (center) and tubules (right) are also apparent in fixed wildtype parasites stained with anti‐UIS4 antibody. Infected cells 24 h post‐infection. Scale bars, 10 µm.

sd-panel.p: Hepatoma cells infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA parasites were fixed and stained with anti-UIS4. C) Often the LS‐TVN is a composite of vesicles, tubules and membrane clusters. Infected cell 22 h post‐infection.

fig.sd-panel: D) The LS‐TVN detectable in primary hepatocytes infected with UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing P. berghei also consists of elongated membrane clusters (yellow arrowhead), vesicles (white arrow) and tubules (yellow arrow). Infected cell 18 h post‐infection.
E) Dynamic tubules (yellow arrow) are detectable with UIS4‐mCherry in infected primary hepatocytes 24 h post‐infection. Location of parasite is marked with a yellow asterisk. Scale bars, 10 µm.

fig.title: Differential labeling of tubules with UIS4 or IBIS1.
fig.label: Figure 3
fig.sd-panel: A) Confocal microscopy images show a tubule (upper panel) labeled with UIS4 and IBIS1 (white arrowheads), an elongated membrane cluster (middle panel) in which both proteins are present, and vesicles (bottom panel) that are often labeled with both UIS4 and IBIS1 (yellow arrow) and frequently labeled with only one protein (yellow arrowheads).

B) Epifluorescence microscopy of IBIS1 and UIS4 reveals that while most tubules are labeled with both proteins as above (white arrowhead), some are labeled exclusively with UIS4 (upper panel) or IBIS1 (bottom panel). Single‐labeled tubules were highlighted with white arrows and their frequency in infected cells with tubules is indicated in percent (± SD), which was calculated from two separate wells 30 h post‐infection (n > 150 infected cells per well).

fig.title: The velocities of the UIS4‐ and IBIS1‐positive features of the LS‐TVN.
fig.label: Figure 4
fig.sd-panel: A‐C) Time‐lapse imaging of hepatoma cells infected with UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing Plasmodium berghei was used to determine the velocities of the UIS4‐positive features, e.g., a tubule (A), elongated membrane cluster (B) and vesicle (C) were tracked over time. Measured speeds of the dynamic features indicated with white arrows are depicted graphically to the right. Scale bars, 10 µm.

D) The velocities of several UIS4‐ or IBIS1‐positive features [tubules (left), elongated membrane clusters (center) and vesicles (right)] were measured over time, and the peak velocity of each was plotted. Plotted data was derived from multiple imaged infected cells: For IBIS1‐positive tubules data is derived from three infected cells and for UIS4‐positive tubules from 13 infected cells. Elongated membrane cluster speeds were analyzed in at least five infected cells for both UIS4 and IBIS1, and vesicle speeds were analyzed in at least 12 different cells for both protein markers.

fig.title: Movement of the LS‐TVN‐associated tubules is dependent on the microtubule network.
fig.label: Figure 5
fig.sd-panel: B) Cells infected with UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing parasites were treated with nocodazole for 1.5 h (top) or cytochalasin D for 30 min (bottom) and imaged by confocal microscopy. Imaging occurred 29 and 24 h post‐infection, respectively. UIS4‐positive tubules, static (top) and dynamic (bottom), are indicated with white arrowheads. Displayed cells are representative of five imaged parasites from at least two different experiments.

B) Cells infected with UIS4‐mCherry‐expressing parasites were treated with nocodazole for 1.5 h (top) or cytochalasin D for 30 min (bottom) and imaged by confocal microscopy. Imaging occurred 29 and 24 h post‐infection, respectively. UIS4‐positive tubules, static (top) and dynamic (bottom), are indicated with white arrowheads. Displayed cells are representative of five imaged parasites from at least two different experiments.

C) No colocalization between host microtubules and UIS4‐positive tubules is detectable. Infected cells were fixed 25 h post‐infection and stained with antibodies against UIS4 and Tubulin. Scale bars, 10 µm.

fig.title: FRAP analysis reveals that the diffusion of UIS4‐mCherry is restricted in most LS‐TVN extended membrane clusters, but free within the PVM.
fig.label: Figure 6
fig.sd-panel: A and B) The bleach was applied to elongated membrane clusters of the LS‐TVN approximately 27 h post‐infection. The UIS4‐mCherry signal typically did not recover in the bleached area (A), although it was found to recover in some elongated membrane clusters (B).

C) When the bleach was applied to the PVM at 25 h post‐infection, the signal recovered rapidly in the bleached region. Upon the application of additional bleach pulses in the same area, the bleached area (region #1 measured graphically) repeatedly recovered, and the remaining PVM‐associated UIS4‐mCherry signal depleted (region #2) although the LS‐TVN‐associated signal remained (region #3). When a region of the LS‐TVN was subsequently bleached (yellow arrow, region #4), no recovery was observed. The times are shown in minutes and seconds. Scale bars, 10 µm.

fig.title: Visualization of UIS4‐positive tubules in infected hepatoma cells by correlative light and electron microscopy (CLEM).
fig.label: Figure 7
fig.sd-panel: A and B) A phase‐contrast image containing the infected cell of interest (A) was used for comparison to the EM grid after fixation and preparation of the cells for TEM (B). Green outlining of the cells in the phase‐contrast image was used as a tool for comparison and alignment. The insets defined in white are shown in the right panels merged with the fluorescent image of the UIS4‐mCherry signal acquired immediately prior to fixation. Scale bars, 10 µm.

C) Detection of the UIS4‐mCherry signal by widefield fluorescence microscopy in the cell of interest immediately prior to fixation. The location of the parasite is marked with an asterisk, and UIS4‐positive features are highlighted with arrowheads.

D) Thirty‐six TEM sections of this sample were prepared and imaged (Movies S4 and S5). Features corresponding to the UIS4‐positive tubule (white arrowhead) were found in sections 10-16 and to the UIS4‐positive signal adjacent to the PVM (yellow arrowhead) were found in Sections 16-29. Sections 11 (top) and 20 (bottom) are displayed to highlight these two features. Scale bars, 1 µm.

fig.title: Late endocytic compartments associate with elongated membrane clusters.
fig.label: Figure 8
fig.sd-panel: A) Hepatoma cells infected with UIS4−mCherry−expressing Plasmodium berghei parasites were fixed 22 h post−infection and stained with antibodies against host cell protein markers of distinct organelles: anti−EEA1 to label early endosomes, anti−CD63 and anti−LAMP1 to label late endosomes and lysosomes, anti−Calnexin to label the endoplasmic reticulum, and anti−Golgin97 to label the Golgi. In all samples, either anti−mCherry or anti−UIS4 was used to amplify the UIS4−mCherry signal. Imaging was carried out by epifluorescence microscopy. In the right panels, fluorescence is merged, and selected regions with areas of interest are shown enlarged. At least 20 infected cells possessing LS−TVN features were visually examined for each condition, and representative images of UIS4−positive elongated membrane clusters (left) and UIS4−positive tubules (right, and indicated with yellow arrows) are displayed. Scale bars, 10 µm.
B) Profiling of the red (UIS4) and green (CD63, left or LAMP‐1, right) signals along the indicated line within the insets from the images in (A) above.

fig.title: LC3 colocalizes with UIS4 on the Plasmodium liver stage PVM and TVNHepatoma cells infected with Plasmodium berghei expressing UIS4‐mCherry (top) or IBIS1‐mCherry (bottom) were fixed 22 h or 48 h post‐infection, respectively, and stained with anti‐LC3 to label autophagic membranes.
fig.label: Figure 9

sd-panel.p: Hepatoma cells infected with Plasmodium berghei expressing UIS4‐mCherry (top) or IBIS1‐mCherry (bottom) were fixed 22 h or 48 h post‐infection, respectively, and stained with anti‐LC3 to label autophagic membranes. In the right panels, fluorescence is merged, and selected areas of interest are shown enlarged. Scale bars, 10 µm.
